snippet: From Moscow to Caracas, Riyadh to Baghdad, in Tehran, Algiers, Kuwait City and Lagos, officials are confronting the plunge in prices — roughly 25 percent since a peak in June.
abstract: Steep decline in oil prices is straining budgets of major petroleum-exporting countries around globe; drop is raising specter of spending cuts in Russia, where the economy is under pressure from Western sanctions, and posing potentially grave security challenge for Iraq, which is already struggling to finance its fight against the Islamic State.

byline.contributor: William Neuman contributed reporting from Caracas, Venezuela.

lead_paragraph: From Moscow to Caracas, Riyadh to Baghdad, in Tehran, Algiers, Kuwait City and Lagos, officials are confronting the plunge in prices — roughly 25 percent since a peak in June.

headline.main: Fall in Oil Prices Poses a Problem for Russia, Iraq and Others
headline.print_headline: Fall in Oil Prices Poses a Problem for Russia, Iraq and Others

keywords.value: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
keywords.name: organizations
